STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 7, 2021
Donata Kidd
Muskegon County DHHS
2700 Baker
Muskegon Heights, MI 49444
RE: License #: CP610201318
Muskegon County DHHS
2700 Baker
Muskegon Heights, MI 49444
Dear Ms. Kidd:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
9/2/2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(517) 284-9740
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP610201318
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768

Name of Facility: Muskegon County DHHS
Facility Address: 2700 Baker
Muskegon Heights, MI 49444
Facility Telephone #: (231) 733-3700

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12326 Borrowed Home
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
One of six borrowed home files reviewed lacked written endorsement on the initial
evaluation prior to the placement of the child. It was signed but not dated.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent then the
reason why return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed
with a relative, then the reason why those placements
are not possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R
400.12404(4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s
age, appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand,
which includes an explanation to all relevant parties as
to why the change is necessary.
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the
new placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
(h) The child’s new location and address.
One of eight foster youth files reviewed lacked the information in subsection (a)
through (h) as required which would have been captured on the action summary
(DHS-69)
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection 10/22/2020, CAP approval dated 12/2/2020
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child’s record, within
7 calendar days after placement, the information specified
in R 400.12417 (1) and all of the following information:
4

(i) Documentation that Native American ancestry was
assessed.
One of eight foster youth files reviewed noted that a youth had Native American
heritage but there was no further documentation in the file that indicated any further
action.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.6 Separation of siblings.
Siblings who enter placement at or near the time same shall
be placed together unless there is documentation that the
placement would be harmful, one of the siblings has
exceptional needs, or the size of the sibling group makes
placement impractical. Notwithstanding efforts to place the
group together.
One of eight foster youth files reviewed has a sibling split that did not have
documentation that indicated why the split occurred.
ISEP 6.10 Relative Foster Home Study
Within 30 days following placement with an unlicensed
relative the agency completes a home study determining
whether the relative should, upon completion of training and
submission of any other required documents, be licensed as
a foster parent.
One of eight foster youth files reviewed had a 3130A that was completed more than
30 days after placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (Previously cited under FOM 722-3B)
Interim Inspection 10/22/2020, CAP approval date 12/2/2020
ISEP 6.24 Visits, Between Siblings
Foster children placed separately from a sibling shall have
at least monthly visits with their siblings who are placed
elsewhere in DHHS foster care custody. All exceptions and
all reasonable steps to ensure that visits take place shall be
documented in the case file.
5

Two of eight foster youth files reviewed did not have the required amount of sibling
visits documented.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Policy violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional DHS Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06H Timely entry of caseworker contacts
The case worker must enter the required face-to-face
contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to face
contacts.
Any face-to-face contact with children, parents, or
caregivers
made by any of the following:
 Foster care caseworker/supervisor
 CPS caseworker/supervisor
 Adoption caseworker/supervisor
 Permanency resource monitors
 Education planners
 Michigan Youth Opportunities Initiative coordinators
Four of eight foster youth files reviewed did not have the require face-to-face
contacts entered into MISACWIS within 5 business days.
FOM 722-07B Permanency planning at 12 months
The caseworker must complete a formal permanency goal
review annually from the acceptance date, or at any time a goal
change is being considered. The DHS-643, Permanency Goal
Review, must be used to document the current permanency
goal, any barriers to the goal, and the action steps that will be
taken to meet the goal. A copy of the form must be filed in the
narrative section of the case file.
One of eight foster youth files reviewed did not have the DHS 643
6

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report must be
completed for every FTM and uploaded into MISACWIS
within 7 days.
Eight of eight foster youth files reviewed were missing the DHS 1105 or it was not
uploaded timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection 10/22/2020, CAP approval dated 12/2/2020
Renewal Inspection 8/28/2019, CAP approval dated 9/19/2019
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 All service plans need to be signed or documented why a signature could not
be obtained.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Contacts that show verification of well-being for a child should document that
the child’s well-being was verified, and the narrative should include specifics
regarding the youth.
 Some contacts were entered with minimal information and noted that worker
will go back later to complete but there were not completed. Field consultant
advised to make sure these were completed prior to approval.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were zero incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency completed investigations, interviewed appropriate parties, and made
findings based on the information gathered, appropriate corrective action plans were
developed and completed. There have been no further incidences of corporal
punishment in the identified homes since that time.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the 2020 Interim Inspection
Report.
A CAP was approved in December 2020 to address personnel records,
fingerprinting, application request, re-evaluation, and license recommendation under
7

foster home certification. It also addressed foster care services: placement, change
of placement, foster parent information, development of service plans, USP’s,
supervisory oversight, worker/child visits, worker/parent visits, PATP and service
agreement signatures, FTM timeframes, placement selection and standards,
supervisory approval, medical passports, dental examination schedule, and DHS 69
Foster Care action summary. The CAP also includes Independent Living services
such as the program statement, policies and procedures, eligibility requirement, IL
contract, and supervision. The CAP is still being utilized and ensures that time
specific self-audits are being used to monitor prior to being in noncompliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s inability to meet certain requirements, such
as obtaining signatures or face to face visits, was due to noncompliant parents. The
assessment also mentioned that limitations due to COVID were also a factor.
The Chief Administrator continued utilization of the CAP and the strategies
implemented will continue to ensure timeliness of case actions and thorough and
accurate documentation. ISP/USP/PWSP checklists will continue to be utilized when
completing reports and reviewed during monthly staffing meetings. MiTEAM
Specialist will assist with monitoring through case reads.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with 3 staff and 2 supervisors onsite. Staff did not report
any concerns and stated that they have worked hard to address concerns that were
brought up from last year’s audit. They felt that the communication is very effective,
and they are notified promptly of any policy updates or changes. Staff reported
feeling supported by supervisors and reported no areas of need.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be
issued a renewal of their regular license.
__ ________9/7/2021___________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
8

Approved By:
September 7, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
